imageAlt: Superior view of a human foot.
stem: The nurse needs to assess the pedal pulse of a client with peripheral artery disease. Click on the location of the Dorsalis Pedis pulse.

rationale.correct: The dorsalis pedis pulse is located on the dorsal (top) surface of the foot, typically lateral to the extensor tendon of the great toe. Assessing this pulse provides information about distal perfusion.
rationale.incorrect: The Lateral Malleolus (h2) is the outer ankle bone where no major pulse is palpated. The Medial Malleolus (h3) is the inner ankle bone; the posterior tibial pulse is palpated BEHIND this bone, not directly on it.
clinicalPearls: Always assess pulses bilaterally to compare strength and symmetry.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't click on the malleolus; the pulse is on the flat dorsal surface of the foot.

stem: The nurse is preparing to administer an IM immunization to a 4-month-old infant. Click on the correct injection site.

rationale.correct: The vastus lateralis (middle third of the lateral thigh) is the preferred IM site for infants because it is the largest, most developed muscle at birth and carries the lowest risk of nerve or vessel injury.
rationale.incorrect: The proximal Rectus Femoris (h2) is not a standard injection site in infants. The Lateral Knee (h3) is a bony joint area and contains no muscle tissue for IM injection.
clinicalPearls: Immunizations in infants are rarely given in the deltoid or gluteal muscles due to insufficient muscle mass.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that the deltoid is used for adults; infants require the thigh (vastus lateralis).

mnemonic.title: V-L
mnemonic.expansion: Very Large muscle for Very Little humans.

stem: The nurse is assessing a client for hepatomegaly. Click on the quadrant where the liver is primarily located.

rationale.correct: The liver is located in the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ). In hepatomegaly, the lower edge of the liver may extend well below the right costal margin.
rationale.incorrect: The Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ) (h1) contains the spleen and stomach. The Right Lower Quadrant (RLQ) (h3) is the primary location for the appendix and cecum.
clinicalPearls: A normal liver edge may be palpated just at the right costal margin during deep inspiration.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The liver is on the Right (RUQ), while the spleen is on the Left (LUQ).

stem: The nurse is auscultating heart sounds. Click on the location of Erb's Point.

rationale.correct: Erb's Point is located at the 3rd Intercostal Space (ICS) on the Left Sternal Border (LSB). It is a central listening point where both S1 and S2 heart sounds are often heard equally.
rationale.incorrect: The Aortic area (h2) is at the 2nd ICS, Right Sternal Border. The Mitral area (h3) is at the 5th ICS, Midclavicular Line.
clinicalPearls: Erb's point is an excellent location for identify murmurs of aortic and pulmonic origin.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Erb's point is the 'extra' point in the middle of the auscultation sequence (3rd ICS).

stem: The nurse is unable to palpate a dorsalis pedis pulse and moves proximal to check flow. Click on the location of the popliteal pulse.

rationale.correct: The popliteal pulse is located deep within the popliteal fossa (behind the knee). It is often easiest to palpate with the knee slightly flexed.
rationale.incorrect: The Achilles area (h2) is at the ankle where the posterior tibial pulse is found (medial side). The hamstring area (h3) is superior to the knee and contains no surface-palpable arterial pulses.
clinicalPearls: The popliteal pulse is often the most difficult of the major pulses to palpate.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: You cannot feel this pulse on the patella; you MUST go behind the knee.

stem: The nurse is auscultating the posterior lung fields. Click on the area representing the Left Lower Lobe.

rationale.correct: On the posterior chest wall, the lower lobes occupy the vast majority of the lower half of the back, beginning below the level of T3 and extending to T10-T12.
rationale.incorrect: The Left Upper Lobe (h2) is located in the apical and superior portion of the posterior chest. The Right Lower Lobe (h3) is on the contralateral side of the spine.
clinicalPearls: Remember that the right lung has three lobes, while the left has only two.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Most of the posterior chest is lower lobe; don't stay too high during auscultation.

imageAlt: Lateral view of the shoulder and upper arm.
stem: The nurse is identifying the landmark for a deltoid IM injection. Click on the correct injection site.

rationale.correct: The correct deltoid site is found 2 to 3 fingerbreadths (1 to 2 inches) below the acromion process. This area provides sufficient muscle mass for small-volume IM injections.
rationale.incorrect: The Acromion process (h2) is a bony landmark where injection would hit the bone. The Triceps area (h3) is lower and posterior, containing large nerves (radial nerve) that must be avoided.
clinicalPearls: Limit deltoid injections to 1 mL of fluid or less.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't hit the acromion bone; stay in the meaty part of the deltoid muscle.

mnemonic.title: D-2
mnemonic.expansion: Deltoid = 2 inches down from the shoulder edge.

stem: The nurse is locating the ventrogluteal site for a deep IM injection. Click on the correct target area.

rationale.correct: The ventrogluteal site is identified by a 'V' shape formed between the index finger on the anterior superior iliac spine and the middle finger along the iliac crest. The injection goes into the center of this triangle.
rationale.incorrect: The Greater Trochanter (h2) is the bony starting point for the palm, not the injection site. The Iliac Crest (h3) is the upper border of the wing of the ilium; injecting directly on the bone is contraindicated.
clinicalPearls: Ventrogluteal is the safest IM site for adults due to thick muscle and lack of large vessels or nerves.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never pick the upper outer quadrant of the buttock (Sciatic risk); always pick the hip.

mnemonic.title: Ventro is Victory
mnemonic.expansion: V-shape for the safest IM injection.

stem: A client is at 20 weeks gestation. Click on the location where the nurse expects to palpate the fundus.

rationale.correct: At 20 weeks of gestation, the uterine fundus is typically palpable at the level of the umbilicus. After this, fundal height in cm usually matches weeks of gestation.
rationale.incorrect: The Symphysis Pubis (h2) is the location at 12 weeks. The Xiphoid Process (h3) is the location at approximately 36 weeks.
clinicalPearls: At 20 weeks, the fundal height measured from the symphysis pubis in centimeters should be approximately equal to the number of weeks of gestation (plus or minus 2 cm).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If fundal height is >2cm from the weeks of gestation, suspect twins or polyhydramnios.

stem: The nurse is assessing the Point of Maximal Impulse (PMI) / Apical Pulse. Click on the correct anatomical location.

rationale.correct: The apical pulse (PMI) is palpated at the 5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line (the Mitral area). This is the apex of the heart.
rationale.incorrect: The Tricuspid area (h2) is at the 4th/5th ICS, Left Sternal Border. Erb's Point (h3) is at the 3rd ICS, Left Sternal Border.
clinicalPearls: The PMI may be displaced lateral or inferior in patients with left ventricular hypertrophy or heart failure.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The apical pulse is out at the midclavicular line, not near the sternum.
